Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 09:31PM paknew wrote: auntiekayro - I don't usually fixate on things either but I'm having such a hard time putting this out of my head.  I'm not freaking out or anything....it's just always there.  I'm having a core biopsy on Tuesday.  I'm not looking forward to that even though I know from here that it's not that bad.  But then I know that after that I have another 5-7 days waiting for the results.  I truly have a gutt feeling that it will be B9 (denial ?) but I just want this to be over already!!! Praying for everyone on here....especially those that have been to the front lines and come to this topic to comfort us.
Posts.Title: feeling lonely,nervous,anxiety ridden auntiekayro GryffinSong

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 08:30AM paknew wrote: ernursen - I'm where you are now.  I was in a panic the first few days but now that it has time to settle in I'm pretty calm.  I still think about it a lot but in a rational way.  I have my consult with the surgeon on Friday and this site has given me an arsenol of knowledge and I won't feel so helpless and scared talking with her.  I suppose the anxiety may rise on that day but I'll be ok.  Life, not just this, is a roller coaster of emotions. I wonder how jazzie is doing.  Wasn't her biopsy today?
Posts.Title: You guys are a source of calmness ernursen ernursen

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 08:34PM paknew wrote: I have a birad 4 for microcalcification and from what I have learned it means that it's about an 80% chance it's benign.  I don't know if it means something different for a lump but I don't think so.  I think everyone on here would say that the waiting and not knowing is really, really hard.  Just try to remember that the odds are in your favor. You're in my thoughts.
Posts.Title: Bi-Rads 4 becky1970 becky1970

Posts.Content: paknew wrote: I recently had a lumpectomy for DCIS and the margins were "really, really clean" according to my surgeon.  She thinks that the area was so small that they got it all during the biopsy.  She did say that there were some atypical cells though.  I was stage 0, grade 3. She suggested that radiation may not even be necessary. They're certain they got all of the cancer since the biopsy of the lumpectomy had no cancer cells in it.  I would be a canditate for the internal SAVI radiation.  I meet with the radiation oncologist tomorrow but would appreciate some thoughts.  I certainly would love to avoid radiation if I can! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Do I really need radiation? paknew PeggySull

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2013 02:21PM paknew wrote: I haven't met with the MO yet.  I think since we're wanting to do the internal radiation (if I have to) we wanted to get the radiation going right away before the cavity left starts to close.  Thanks for the advice and especially the hugs!
Posts.Title: Do I really need radiation? paknew PeggySull

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2013 12:47PM paknew wrote: I wish I could help you Peggy.  I think you'll feel better after you talk to the RO.  I was stressing over the decision to be made until I met with him.  It's so much to absorb though.  But like BrooksideVT said, the RO is treat what already happened...to make sure they got everytihing.  The MO, at least in my case (I didn't need chemo) is to try to lower your risk or reccurrance. My heart and prayers go out to you!!
Posts.Title: Do I really need radiation? paknew PeggySull

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2013 10:33AM paknew wrote: Hi Sandie, Thanks so much for your information!  It's very comforting because I decided to NOT do radiation after the consulation with the RO.  He also used the Van Nuys Prognotic Index and said because of my age (48) and grade (3), he would support my decision to have radiation but because of the size of the area and stage (0) etc. he would also support my decision to not have it. It wasn't easy but I'm at peace and happy with it. Thanks again!!!!
Posts.Title: Do I really need radiation? paknew PeggySull

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 10:48PM paknew wrote: I wish there were something I could say to make you feel better.  It sounds like you're in good hands and they're going to do everything they can to make you ok.  Your life really has been turned upside down, huh?  I'm so sorry you're going through this. Extra hugs for you tonight.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 04:30PM paknew wrote: fallenangel, There are many, many reasons you may be feeling this way.  Don't jump to the conclusion that you have cancer.  You need to call your doctor and get it checked out but it's probably nothing.  Try not to be too scared! Hugs!
Posts.Title: i'm so scared fallenangel my3girls

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 02:37PM paknew wrote: Baywatcher - BC doesn't always start with a lump.  I had microcalcs that were caught on the mamogram.  It ended up being benign but 20% of women with microcalcs do have cancer.  There are no early signs like a lump with that.
